courses.title: Principles of Neuroscience for non-majors
courses.description: Students will learn fundamental principles and methods in neuroscience from problem-based study of the neural substrates of animal behavior. For Non-Neuroscience Majors.

courses.title: NEUR 2000 Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for NEUR 2000.

courses.title: Principles in Neuroscience
courses.description: Students will learn fundamental principles and methods in neuroscience from problem-based study of te neural subtrates of animal behavior.

courses.title: Introduction to Neuroscience Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for NEUR 2001.

courses.title: Principles of Neuroscience for Majors
courses.description: Students will learn fundamental principles and methods in neuroscience through problem-based study of the neural substrates of animal behavior. For Non-Neuroscience Majors.

courses.title: Principles of Neuroscience Lab
courses.description: Students will learn fundamental techniques and methods in neuroscience from activities, experiments, and problem-based study of the neural substrates of animal behavior. For Neuroscience Majors.

courses.title: NEUR 2010 Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for NEUR 2010.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Special Problems.

courses.title: Cell and Molecular Neuroscience
courses.description: An overview of principles and techniques in cell and molecular neuroscience: neuron excitability, synaptic transmission, learning and memory to basic mechanisms of neurological diseases.

courses.title: Neural Systems, Networks, and Behavior
courses.description: This course explores how animal behaviors emerge from neuronal networks and systems, with a specific focus on principles of network operation and computational applications.

courses.title: Neuroscience of Behavior
courses.description: This course examines the biological basis of psychology. Behavioral Neuroscience is an interdisciplinary science that aims to investigate the interaction between brain and behavior. Credit will not be awarded for PSYC 4020 and NEUR 3003.

courses.title: Methods in Neuroscience
courses.description: The course is focused on understanding how information about brain and nervous system function can be determined from a wide range of experimental and data analysis techniques.

courses.title: Introduction to Neuroengineering
courses.description: An introduction to the intersection between neuroscience and neurotechnology, including identification of key aspects of the nervous system as the basis for measurement and intervention.

courses.title: Neuroscience Research Project
courses.description: Focused on multidisciplinary perspectives in neuroscience, this course requires that students utilize and apply the skills and knowledge developed over the course of their major.

courses.title: Neurodevelopment
courses.description: An introduction to the principles of developmental biology of the nervous system, more specifically how neurons and born and connect to one another to form a nervous system.

courses.title: Functional Neuroanatomy
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to learn the functional organization of nervous systems with an emphasis on mammalian central and peripheral neuroanatomy.

courses.title: Ion Channels in Health and Disease
courses.description: We will examine the role of ion channels in diverse human diseases and learn basic biophysical properties, structure, normal physiology and pharmacology of ion channels.

courses.title: Neuroscience of Memory
courses.description: How does the nervous system support learning and memory? How does memory guide behavior and decisions? Course emphasizes mammalian brain, but students consider fundamental mechanisms.

courses.title: Neuroendocrinology
courses.description: An introduction to study of the interactions of the nervous and endocrine systems, specifically covering how the brain regulates the hormonal activity in the body.

courses.title: Neuroscience Thesis Research
courses.description: A course in which selected students conduct original research under the direction of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistantship
courses.description:
Neuroscience teaching assistantship for pay under the guidance of a faculty member. Permit only.
Note: This course cannot count toward Neuroscience Electives or Free Electives.

courses.title: Undergraduate Teaching Experience
courses.description: An introduction to teaching neuroscience for undergraduate teaching assistants, with a focus on effective teaching, active engagement of students, and development of innovative classroom activities.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Neuroethics
courses.description: This course considers the implications of neuroscience research on culture, society, the legal system, and on how individuals conceive of their nature as human beings.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of current interest not included in the regular course offerings.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Special Problems.

courses.title: Principles of Neuroscience and Neurotechnology
courses.description: This course provides an overview of the underlying biological processes that give rise to neural activity.

courses.title: Neurophysiology
courses.description: The course will focus on function and adaptations of muscular and neural systems. Interactions among the various systems and their plasticity will be emphasized.

courses.title: Cognitive Neuroscience
courses.description: This course examines the foundations of Cognitive Neuroscience, including the biological mechanisms underlying cognition, the dominant theories, and the experimental techniques.

courses.title: Doctoral Research
courses.description: Doctoral research.
